item.title: Coronavirus: Government urges 'caution' on lockdown easing
item.description: Changes could be incremental and vary between nations, but media reports "are not a reliable guide".

item.title: Bank of England warns of sharpest recession on record
item.description: Bank head Andrew Bailey tells the BBC there will be no quick return to normality after the hit to jobs and income.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK claps for carers for the seventh week
item.description: Watch for bagpipes, Boris Johnson and bus drivers showing off their parking skills.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Maximum caution' from the PM and UK recession warnings
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this evening

item.title: Coronavirus: NHS reveals source code behind contact-tracing app
item.description: More than 40,000 people have downloaded the contact tracing app so far, ahead of a wider release.

item.title: Ex-Trump adviser Michael Flynn charges of lying to FBI dropped
item.description: Michael Flynn pleaded guilty two years ago to lying to the FBI shortly before Mr Trump took office.

item.title: Coronavirus: Paris restrictions to stay as France reopens
item.description: Measures will be relaxed from Monday, but the densely populated capital faces continuing curbs.

item.title: Coronavirus: Black Britons face 'twice the risk' of death, says ONS
item.description: Location and wealth do not fully explain the risk compared with white people, new analysis suggests.

item.title: Coronavirus: More worried about boredom, stress and anxiety than general health
item.description: The Office for National Statistics asked how coronavirus was affecting people's lives.

item.title: Coronavirus: Bank holiday warning to avoid beauty spots
item.description: Emergency services and other authorities say travel to beaches and national parks will "cost lives".

item.title: Coronavirus: Scam sites selling masks and fake cures taken down
item.description: More than 160,000 suspicious emails have been reported to a new scam-busting service in two weeks.

item.title: Students 'being ignored' over fee-refund claim
item.description: MPs consider a petition signed by 330,000, asking for students to get money back on fees this year.

item.title: Serkis: ‘Hobbit reading will take you on an adventure’
item.description: Gollum actor Andy Serkis is doing a continuous live reading of The Hobbit for charity.

item.title: Coronavirus: Lockdown lives behind each door
item.description: With the UK in its seventh week of lockdown, how different have people's experiences been?

item.title: Coronavirus: Duchess of Cambridge launches portraits photo project
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge hopes Hold Still will show "what everyone is going through at this time".

item.title: Coronavirus: All dressed up and nowhere to go
item.description: Photographer Robin Sinha asked his neighbours in Walthamstow, London, to pose on their doorsteps.

item.title: VE Day 2020: England prepares for lockdown celebrations
item.description: How are communities in England preparing to celebrate VE Day in lockdown?

item.title: Axl Rose and Steven Mnuchin in coronavirus Twitter spat
item.description: Guns n' Roses singer Axl Rose insulted Mnuchin over the government's handling of the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why do I need to be tested?
item.description: BBC Reality Check breaks down what coronavirus testing is and why it matters.

item.title: VE Day choir sings online to entertain Worcestershire pensioners
item.description: Joan and Don, both in isolation, share their VE Day memories as an online choir entertains them.

item.title: How the Covid-19 pandemic is threatening Africa’s wildlife
item.description: Park rangers in Africa say the closure of safari tourism is leading to an increase in poaching.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Would you report people who break the rules?
item.description: A hotline in New York was mocked for encouraging "snitches" but in Singapore citizen police are out.

item.title: Coronavirus: Will we ever shake hands again?
item.description: Will Covid-19 make handshakes a relic of the past? If so, what might that mean about the future of human touch and interaction?

item.title: Coronavirus contact-tracing: World split between two types of app
item.description: The UK is testing its own design but a Google-Apple initiative is winning over many other nations.

item.title: VE Day 2020: How is it being celebrated this year?
item.description: Coronavirus means people are marking the 75th anniversary of VE Day from their own homes.

item.title: Coronavirus: Lockdown bites poor as France eases grip
item.description: France is eyeing a lifting of strict coronavirus measures on Monday but for many the damage is done.

item.title: Why 2020 'is a write-off' for gigs and festivals
item.description: A top virologist, bioethicist, and music boss on the impact of Covid-19 on hosting big events.

item.title: Coronavirus: Will offices be safe for a return to work?
item.description: Here's a look at some of the technology that might help monitor the health of employees.

item.title: Coronavirus: The health advice that is misleading or worse
item.description: There's still plenty of dangerous and untested medical advice circulating online.

item.title: Coronavirus: Texas banned abortions - how did that affect women?
item.description: In Texas, abortions are resuming as virus restrictions ease - but for many, the damage has been done.

item.title: Clubs discuss variety of kick-off times and free-to-air options
item.description: Premier League clubs discuss increasing the variety of kick-off times and the option of free-to-air games if the season resumes.

item.title: Saracens players apologise for lockdown breach
item.description: Saracens say they are disappointed with a group of players spotted breaking government rules on social distancing.

item.title: F1 may not race in 2020, say bosses, as sport reports losses
item.description: Formula 1 chairman Chase Carey has admitted that the sport's owners are preparing for "the remote possibility of no racing in 2020".

item.title: Three Fiorentina players test positive for coronavirus
item.description: Three Fiorentina players and three members of the club's support staff test positive for coronavirus.

item.title: Evander Holyfield to make ring return as Mike Tyson eyes same move
item.description: As two heavyweight legends look set to box in charity bouts, could we see one final contest between Evander Holyfield and Mike Tyson?

item.title: Newcastle will pay £70m for Coutinho - gossip
item.description: Newcastle will spend big on Coutinho and Koulibaly, Arsenal open to Icardi and Aubameyang swap, plus more.

item.title: Jamie Chadwick column: Indoor cycling, Zoom chats and banana cake
item.description: W Series champion Jamie Chadwick talks about how she is finding life in lockdown, with exercise, Zoom chats and cooking helping to pass the time.

item.title: Coronavirus: Am I at risk during pregnancy?
item.description: What are the risks of passing the virus to the baby in the womb, or of premature birth?

item.title: Why are more people from BAME backgrounds dying from coronavirus?
item.description: People from ethnic minorities have been hard hit by coronavirus in the US, but what about the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do British people still accept the lockdown?
item.description: Many say they would be uncomfortable leaving home even if restrictions were lifted.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will children be returning to school?
item.description: Schools have been closed to most pupils since the end of March - when and how will they open?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why did the UK need 100,000 tests a day?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: The FBI said I was my parents' stolen baby - but I found the truth
item.description: Foundling Paul Fronczak was given to a family whose baby had been stolen - but was he really their son?
